title: Will Vladimir Putin cease to be the president of the Russian Federation before 1 January 2022?
preds: Pending death, it is unlikely he will ever step down. He must find a successor that he trusts to protect his interest and life when stepping down.
Did anyone really think this was a possibility?
I doubt he intends to die in the next month. He will only leave the Kremlin feet first!
Can we close this one yet?  Short of death, he is not going anywhere this year.
Strong grip on power, recent elections and polls show support

The next presidential election is not until March 2024. Unless Vladimir Putin unexpectedly dies (whether by illness, accident, or assassination, all are which are very unlikely), there is little chance that he will cease to be president by 1 Jan 2022.
It's hard to imagine a scenario where Putin ceases to be the president of the Russian Federation that does not involve him dying, and therefore seems extremely unlikely.
Can we resolve this one yet?  I know there are still several months, but there is no sign Putin is leaving anytime soon, if ever.
Too much to lose by stepping down.
Downward due to time and a lack of any reason to deviate from the base rate of "yes, since always"
No change. I thought this piece was interesting: https://www.politico.com/news/magazine/2021/09/04/us-president-putin-russia-democracy-504417

Bear wrestling is more likely. 
Plus 1

https://www.nytimes.com/2021/08/25/world/europe/navalny-jail-prison.html
https://www.nytimes.com/2021/08/25/world/europe/navalny-interview-excerpts.html In today’s Russia, Mr. Navalny made clear, hours spent watching state television and movies chosen by the warden are the experience of a political prisoner, a status Amnesty International has assigned to Mr. Navalny. Gone are the shifts of heavy labor in mining or forestry and the harrying by criminals and guards alike that was the hallmark of the Soviet gulag for political prisoners. “The Putin regime is an historical accident, not an inevitability,” he wrote, adding, “It was the choice of the corrupt Yeltsin family,” a reference to former President Boris N. Yeltsin’s appointment of Mr. Putin as acting president in December 1999. “Sooner or later, this mistake will be fixed, and Russia will move on to a democratic, European path of development. Simply because that is what the people want.” Through the 20th century and earlier, prison in Russia was a crucible that forged or broke dissidents and writers, molded leaders and crushed pluralistic politics. “Putin solved his tactical question: not allowing us to take away the majority in the Duma,” Mr. Navalny said, speaking of the Russian Parliament’s lower house. “But to achieve this, he had to completely change the political system, to shift to a principally different, far harsher level of authoritarianism.” This is far and away more sophisticated. They won’t beat you — quite the opposite, with continual provocation, they will put you in a position where you have to beat up somebody else, hit somebody, threaten somebody. And then the deed is done — there are video cameras everywhere, and the administration with great pleasure will open a new criminal case against you on charges of assault, adding a few years to your sentence. To not succumb to provocation, this is the most important thing to learn here.
We can probably close this question.  There is no way that Putin is going anywhere anytime soon or ever if he has his way.
Down 1% for passage of time. Doesn't really impact brier though.
I am still holding at 2%  only for health or bear wrestling accidents.
Unless a black swan happens in Russia, at this moment in time I do not see Putin stepping down.

Taking into account the election process (next election is in 2024), health, age, the possibility of volitionally leaving the post, and the possibility of being forced out before the closing date of the question, I would say it's a di minimus probability that Putin will leave office by the closing date of the question. So, I am forecasting 0% unless someone presents evidence to the contrary (I've read the comments below).

only if his health gets in his way - there seem to be intermittent reports that something is up (for example https://jamestown.org/program/behind-the-rumors-of-putins-illness-distraction-or-signal-of-looming-changes-at-the-top/) but its thin on detail and very difficult to interpret what it all means. Ill health is only one of several reasons for this speculation.  but he  is 68, in a stressful job, likely without much room to stumble, and no clean option to retire - in general we wouldn't be surprised if he had a catastrophic failure. this chart, to my surprise, https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SP.DYN.LE00.IN?locations=RU suggests that life expectancy for men in russia has improved from 65 years to 74 years in the last 10 years. and of course Putin likely gets top notch health care and appears to be in good shape for a 68 year old (although i haven't seen him wrestling a bear or participating in armwresting competition recently) overall - i think its extremely unlikely he will retire or be forced out, and slightly less likely that a health event will decommission him.
no way. He'll be there in 2024 even.
No stories of ill health for Putin and having cleared most of the opposition out of the system for the September election, Putin rules almost completely. So, joining the crowd for now.
Not unless he dies by "heart attack" or "short illness."

Serious? The only way he would leave before 1/1/22 is in a coffin. The chances of 68 y.o. American dying is about 2% in 12 months, according to SSA.  Theres only 5 months left until Jan. 1 so I figure maybe 1% chance of this happening.

UK journalist sued by Russian billionaire over Putin book - Associated Press
https://apnews.com/article/sports-government-and-politics-business-europe-russia-7d9a08ab67d7a3a14bfaa5c7a9ed478d
Wed, 28 Jul 2021 16:07:30 GMT
It could happen but is quite unlikely.

Nothing on the horizon to indicate a need to change my forecast. Albeit the man is not looking as healthy in recent press pictures as he was in 2019 and earlier. He also seems to be 'eliminating' potential opposition candidates, ahead of upcoming elections, fairly effectively.  IMO, he looks fairly well entrenched and I've not seen anything about his health being seriously questionable. Thus, it seems a rogue assassin is the only risk with this question.
@sevedb /  @dowser  /
Maybe if we were talking something like 1 January 2032 my forecast would be higher than zero.  This guy is not going anywhere anytime soon.
Only if he forgets his "Code" word...
Highly unlikely, going with the crowd here...
About a quarter of the year gone, and no major changes, so dropping proportionally
Step down or resign 0.   Other causes  1 in 50.
Should have read the question better.. in consideration of all other causes have revised my forecast.

Putin's popularity is declining, but there are little to no signs that his grip on power is endanger.  The situation could evolve quickly, but at the moment it remains highly unlikely Putin will step down or overthrown this year.
Down 5% for passage of time and to be closer to the consensus.

One can't put a number on death by stroke, heart attack, assassination, and such singular events. Chance of being voted out = 0%, chance of being couped by oligarchs = 2% (though popular sentiment can increase this), chance of stepping down = 0%. An average of 1% seems fair. Also consider his consistent attempts, and success, at rewriting the law to allow for himself to stay on further for two more terms. While the argument is that it'll keep his seconds in command at their toes, it's hard to see him planning to step down, at least in practice. A name change is not out of the question though.
Agree with @LokiOdinevich, the treatment of Navalny increase popular discontent.
Going marginally up on Nalvany's gambit
Just for standard health reasons in his age.

Several days ago, Putin signed a law into effect that allows him to run for two more terms. Barring a health issue - which we have no indication to believe is likely - he's likely to continue as president.
Down 10% for passage of time & to reflect the consensus.
No, there is little chance this will happen.
Reducing forecast due to no new information on health issues OECD better life index and passage of time.
He has shown very little interest in stepping down. Barring revelations of some kind of health issue, he will continue in his present role.
It will be as long as his health helps him, certainly longer than 2022.  The new law allows him to be president until 2036.
Can always have a heart attack...Russian style.....
This feels unlikely, the succession planning will take longer than the remainder of this year
Down 15%. I think my narrative was a bit naive.
Given the protests, there is a chance, however small. Also, he is of a certain age, although in good physical form.

As options for Russia go, he's still the best.  His popularity still consistently rates highly among Russians, and more recently in the face of Western "wokeness", he's seen as a bit of an antidote to that cancer, winning him the same sort of favour in foreign countries that Trump did across the pond and in other countries where the population prefer to live by a rule of comparative sanity / normality.  He isn't going to stand-down, and I don't think any foreign interference will do anything to budge him (quite the opposite).  If he passes away of natural causes I wouldn't be surprised if Russia had him stuffed and put back in his seat.  It's a zilch from me.
Vladimir Putin wird alles daran setzen die Dauer seiner Allmacht Russland auszuweiten.
Russian people will not rise against him within next 2 years and he won't quit himself

As always 3 ways to stop being president, die, resign out of free will, or be forced to resign.  Putin resigning out of free will I assume to be very unlikely. There is no real succession plan, no real hints about Putin wanting to quit, and he just strike me a someone wo loves power and would go a long way to stay in power. The corruption rumors (if true) will also make it a bad decision to quit. Still, you can never be sure so I give a 1% change on this count. Dying, always hard to predict. As @smingers notes he seems to be in good health and has access to top health care.  Still he's approaching 70 and he wouldn't be the first to die in office. There's also Covid-19. Add 2% point. Forced to resign. On the one hand, there seems to be a lot of resentment inside Russia, living standards are in decline and protests are common. On the other hand Putin seems to have a tight grasp on the security service. Going with 2% point here bringing me to 5% change total.  https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/01/29/pandemic-pushed-russians-household-finances-to-decade-low-a72773
http://www.oecdbetterlifeindex.org/countries/russian-federation/
How does this get scored if he resigns as President to take a newly created position called, say, "Бог" which will exempt him from those pesky elections?

https://www.politico.com/news/magazine/2021/03/15/russia-putin-invasion-ukraine-baltics-nato-475527
https://www.ft.com/content/59498c92-799f-4c61-ac2e-77e7e302cc32
https://www.rt.com/russia/516680-putin-presidency-fifth-term/ https://www.newstatesman.com/world/europe/2021/03/why-russians-still-choose-vladimir-putin-s-stability-over-alexei-navalny-s Putin won’t go quietly and not this year unless something unprecedented happens in the election.
Even if he did go who would replace him?  Often people feel better the devil you know, so much as there is support for him going from younger people who don’t remember soviet times, or in many cases, any other leader, older people are likely to be more cautious and would need to feel that they are not trading Putin in for someone worse.  Russia today is still better than it was 30 years ago.

Putin is 68 years old and reportedly a non-smoker, light drinker, and heavy exerciser. One assumes he has access to world-class medical care. There are rumors about Parkinsons. He is, presumably, in a very stressful job and has been for decades. I don't see him willingly leaving office in the next year, so I go with the consensus.

"Clad in a light-brown sheepskin overcoat that fell over his wool felt boots, Vladimir Putin strode from a dacha outside Moscow across the thick snow. It was 17 degrees below zero on the morning of January 19. Putin disrobed, draping the coat over a wooden railing, and stepped out of his boots. Wearing just a pair of blue swimming shorts, he descended through a crucifix-shaped hole cut in the six-inch-thick ice, wading into the frigid water."
https://www.ft.com/content/59498c92-799f-4c61-ac2e-77e7e302cc32 =================
COMMENTS: I think Putin will only leave the Kremlin "feet first," after this new macho display he is not yet ready to leave neither the Kremlin, nor power, and not even life. Not on its own will anyway.

This answer because of the time will resolve no.
Only a health related problem will stop him.
Today Putin signed a new bill extending his reign 2036 
https://www.cbsnews.com/amp/news/vladimir-putin-president-russia-signs-law-allowing-2-more-presidential-terms/
The only chance that he will cease to be president is from death, and he is reportedly in good health.
Updating for passage of time and moving towards consensus.
Unless he gets hit by a bus or has a heart attack, he isn't going anywhere

Putin's daughters have a large amount of influence on him and they are concerned about his health. Putin has put in place lifetime protection from criminal prosecution for ex-presidents, a permanent seat in the Senate, and continued persecution of his detractors. He is building a new Residence at Cape Idokopas, an Italian style palace near the Black Sea. Pro-Putin majorities in government offices and the legislature indicate a man who is preparing to retire in comfort while he continues to influence the direction and policies of the Russian government.
Putin is loved by many of the Russian people and they believe he is best for their country leadership.

Vladimir Putin will not hold on to power forever, I believe there is a higher chance than many think that he will leave the position before 2022. Much of his seemingly unlimited power from recent constitutional amendments comes with an interesting emergency exit strategy. Couple this emergency exit plan with Russia's increased reliance on the east, a strategy not believed to be favorable due to old fears of Chinese interests in Eastern Russia, and you have an interesting problem. Pro-Navalny protests have blackened Putin's "eye" permanently. Many factors sway my vote here, but I suspect Putin will not in power for long.

A referendum was passed in 2020 that allows Vladimir Putin to continue as president until 2036. He will not remain in power forever but for the time being, he will hold the presidency unless he dies before then or decides to retire.

Highly unlikely, and the timeframe is too short to accommodate it even were he to be contemplating it already.  But there is always a chance of death (natural or assassination) that seems to me underestimated other respondants.

President Vladimir Putin has controlled Russian politics, since succeeding Boris Yeltsin as leader in 1999. Even though he is eligible for reelection in 2024, there has been discussions that he will step down. The Kremlin has “denied reports that Russian President Vladimir Putin is planning to step down due to health problems”(Drewett, Zoe). Putin’s team has said that he is in great health and has no current intentions on resigning. There will be a 1% chance of him stepping down.
He’s not one to let go of secrets nor comforts.
Reducing as I don't think he can leave currently with Navalny backlash.

We have looked at the political, social, economic, military and health reasons the Putin will leave office and only the health reason seems reasonable enough. Putin's speculated parkinson's diseases can take anywhere from 10-20years to progress. The chance of him leaving office within the year is low. However, the lifetime immunity that was put into place for former presidents shows that there are inclinations of him thinking about leaving office.
He will hold on to his power.
He would have to die in office.

Foreign Minister SERGEJ LAVROV dies
next foreign ministar SERGEJ SOJGU
No sign of this happening, little internal descent , his health seems to be good.

No election in this time period and no upside to him personally for stepping down. Health reasons or death are the only likely outcomes that would cause him to step down. He appears to be healthy (not that the Russian media would tell us otherwise).

The trouble with unchecked power: Why Putin will never leave - European Council on Foreign Relations
https://ecfr.eu/article/the-trouble-with-unchecked-power-why-putin-will-never-leave/
Thu, 18 Feb 2021 14:15:15 GMT

Putin controls the levers of the Russian state's power in terms of the largest political party, the military, and has a large majority of public support. It seems extremely unlikely that Putin would lose power in Russia except by sudden death, despite the fact he appears healthy and relatively young, or a very unexpected revolution. I don't believe that the chance of this occurring is quite 0% or 1% at this point, given historical examples of leaders dying in office over the course of 11 months and revolutions in general. The average rate of chiefs of state dying over the last 20 years in office is about 2.25 per year, which would imply about a 1% chance. With the additive chance of revolution from protests, which Russia has suffered two of over the last 105 years (2% per year). I would estimate a probability of about 3% all other things being equal. Given that Putin is slightly older than the average chief of state and protests are on-going from the jailing of Navalny I would bump that probability up slightly to 5%.   Sources: 
https://www.forbes.com/profile/vladimir-putin/?sh=5cb742766fc5
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_heads_of_state_and_government_who_died_in_office
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_Revolution
He might die- not sure we have good information on his health- otherwise very low chance
Maybe I’ll call a psychic hotline for some good info?

Reducing estimate due passage of time and consensus. I don’t believe EU sanction and dismissal of Diplomates by both sides will apply any pressure on Putin’s presidency. 
While the Nord Stream 2 project continues both parties reactions will be limited.  https://www.reuters.com/article/us-russian-politics-navalny-sanctions-idUSKBN2AI1WU
https://www.politico.eu/article/nord-stream-2-is-one-hundred-percent-anti-ukrainian-ukrainian-deputy-minister-says/
Is it possible Putin will fake his own death. So he can be a Starbucks employee in the movie idiocracy?
There doesn't seem to be any urgency connected with a Putin/Biden meeting. In fact it may be in the United States interest to downplay Putin's importance for the time being.

I think most of the breathless reporting on how threatened he is by the demonstrations and the anger of the population is the equivalent of all the breathless reporting on how Republicans would turn against Trump over the past four years.

Of course, Putin won't give up of his own will. The purpose of this question is because of the rumors about his health, and his signing of lifetime immunity to ex-Presidents. Well in Russia there are no other ex-Presidents, except Dmitry Medvedev (May 7, 2008 — May 7, 2012). Yeltsin is resting in peace, no need for immunity for him. He must have been thinking of himself when he drafted that immunity.
However, if the (hypothetical) disease is a reality but can be under control, January 2022 is not far enough. Putin did withdraw from the public eye for a long period a few years back. Therefore, if he really has a debilitating health issue we would start being suspicious soon enough.

Legislation has passed granting former presidents a lifetime position in the federation council, effectively giving former presidents immunity from prosecution. Putin has a path to continue ruling and a path to retire. I think that if he has plans to retire they were jeopardized by the actions of his political rivals over the past few months. If he was setting up a way to resign he needs to minimize the risk of a political opponent finding a way to gain power. The odds of a Putin opponent gaining power seem miniscule but they also seem to be rising. Increased odds of a political opponent gaining power if he leaves is an incentive for him to stay in power.  I think the measurable odds are on his survival. The average Russian life expectancy is 71, Putin being wealthy & protected from violence puts himself in a better position to maintain his health. The probability of death for a 68 year old man in 2017 according to the Us social Security was 0.019693. Putin's resources should put him at an advantage in maintaining his health. An assumption can place him near 1%.  I'm basing my forecasts on Putin's ability to stay healthy in office, I don't think this is the best approach. Putin's Keys to power must continue to see him as a reliable benefactor, that may be unrelated to his health. I think that judging his supporters faith in him may have a more accurate forecast.  https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/dec/22/putin-signs-bill-granting-lifetime-immunity-to-former-russian-presidents https://www.ssa.gov/oact/STATS/table4c6.html#fn1

Barring some serious health issue I'd  expect him to stay in power. As mentioned by others his new legislation seems to position for all futures. Working against him are the recent bungled attempt on Navalny and his subsequent court case, but we have seen opposition quietened in the past. Russia's COVID deaths are also high (3rd highest in the world) and the economic recovery is threatened by shortages of immigrant workers.
Stranger things have happened but I think it would take more than 11 months to pry him loose even if there was a real threat to his power.
Don't think Putin is going to give up.

I think he is planning for a future where he isn't president but still holds power (the law that lets him run two more times also gives ex-presidents lifetime immunity from criminal prosecution), but don't think it will happen this year. He is only 68 unless we get more substantiated reporting on health issues it seems unlikely he would need to step down.   Especially unlikely with the Navalny business going on,  why step down when the logical thing to use your power to put down opposition. It's possible he'd find a way to stop being president, install a puppet in office and exercise power from elsewhere but I don't see any likely path toward that in the short term.
Only due to the rumors about his disease (Parkinson's).

The only way Putin will relinquish power is over his dead body...
Putin is 68 and the average healthy male western (he has those benefits) has an 11.87 in 1000 or 1% chance of death from natural causes. I've added 4% for unnatural causes.
No chance. He is going to hang on until the bitter end.
If he steps down, his personal risk goes up. I would mot count on the presumed loyalty of any presumed, selected successor. He may leave office due to severe illness or death. He is getting older.
Putin is 67 years old. Average mortality of Male Russians is 65.1 in 2013.
That’s gonna be a “no” for me, dogg.
Nyet. Not even sure he could quit - too many dependent on status quo. Always a chance he could slip into some novichuk underwear I guess...
Putin has a stranglehold on Russia.  My belief that he will only cease to be president if he dies.
If he hasn’t stepped down this far, what has changed now?
Actuarial probability for Putin to die this year.

Putin has been in power since August 1999 (22 years). Putins current approval rating is 64% (previous lowest approval rating was 61% in 2013) https://www.statista.com/statistics/896181/putin-approval-rating-russia/ Putin seems to be in good health, but there are rumors of an illness. But this is the likeliest, since it would have to be choice by Putin to step down and focus on recovery.
https://www.reuters.com/article/uk-russia-putin-health/uk-media-report-that-putin-is-ill-and-poised-to-quit-is-nonsense-says-kremlin-idUKKBN27M17H Putin still has a strong grip on the political aparatus
2000 won 53% of the vote
2004 won 79% of the vote
2012 won 63% of the vote
2018 won 76% of the vote Putin is not up for re-election until 2024. A coup, judical, political or military, is unlikely since all seem to depend on Putin for power. Previous leaders age at death or current age
Putin 68 still alive
Yeltsin 76 at death
Gorbachev 89 still alive
Chernenko 73 at death
Andropov 69 at death
Brezhnev 75 at death
Khrushchev 77 at death
Stalin 74 at death
Average 76 Therefore the following are the odds for possible outcomes for ceasing to be President before Jan 1, 2022
Death 10%
Loose Power through Resignation 10%
Loose Power by Coup 1%
Loose Power by Electoral Defeat 0%
Do oligarchs willingly give up power? Nope. He'll be around for a while.

In looking at the long serving leaders of Post-Soviet Countries like Russia' Vladimir Putin who are ranked as not free ->
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Post-Soviet_states#Politics Of those who are gone, they either died in office or resigned in their late 70-80's. With Putin still at a relatively youthful 68, I consider him ceasing to be President of Russia this year a very unlikely possibility. The most plausible possibility I think is of him resigning as President but retaining the power through another office like what happened in Kazakhstan ->
 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nursultan_Nazarbayev Of the possibility of his removal by a revolution or coup, at the moment I don't see any indications of either.
5% for mortality, and illness.  No signs of weakness in hit power base so riots and assinations are not in play.  Economics point to a better year as commodities recover late in 2021.
2% for health issue / death, but otherwise he'll be in power

The stories referenced in this question point to interesting developments in the Russian political sphere - specifically, that Putin is rumored to have some health problems (Parkinson's?) and additionally, that he signed a bill late last year to give ex-presidents and their families lifetime immunity for crimes committed in their lifetimes. Alone, that might be another indicator that he could be looking more closely at life after Presidency, but I note that earlier this year, he also made changes to the constitution that would allow him to run for two more 6-year terms, the first of which wouldn't even start until 2024.  So! We have a report of ailing health and a new law shielding ex-presidents from prosecution for life. On the other side of the ledger...dude has been president forever, rides around on horses bareback (and shirtless), and he's pretty popular, especially among the generation old enough to remember life in Russia (and the USSR?) before him. Additionally, one would think that if the Parkinson's rumor is true, he would have had at least some indication of it when he signed the "two more 6-year terms" law last year. Seems unlikely that would be at the top of his to-do list if he thought he might barely make it halfway through his current term. If the question were longer term, I might raise my probability, and this bares keeping an eye on, but for now, my estimate is very low.

Putin remains popular in Russia. It’s more than possible that he will step down in the near future but this will be a gradual process. 
His health may be of concern but these rumours have come and gone for several years and he remains in office.

“There are decades where nothing happens; and there are weeks where decades happen.” 
― Vladimir Ilyich Lenin “The Russians are slow to saddle up, but ride fast”
- Bismark “I cannot forecast to you the action of Russia. It is a riddle wrapped in a mystery inside an enigma. But perhaps there is a key. That key is Russian national interest.”	 
- Winston Churchill	 Russia has the ability of to provide cataclysmic changes in a brief period after long periods of stagnation i.e., the fall of the Tsar culminating in the Russian revolution and the fall of the Soviet Union.
However, at the moment Putin is relatively popular (the older the demographic, the more popular) and he appears to be in good health (contrary to reports in the UK tabloids).
In 2020 Putin changed the Russian constitution to extend the presidential term limits and allow him to stay in power until 2036, this was supported by 79% vote in a referendum. He does not run again for election until 2024 and has not stated any intention to do so, but there are no obvious candidates for succession on the horizon. https://www.newsweek.com/vladimir-putin-russia-popular-politician-1556686  https://www.newyorker.com/news/q-and-a/how-putin-controls-russia  https://www.voanews.com/europe/how-putin-preparing-2021-challenges
https://www.forbes.com/sites/jamesrodgerseurope/2020/12/19/russia-in-2021-six-things-to-watch/?sh=3d5e710222d7

So this feels low-ish probability. No signs from him that he wants to steps down and he has successfully ruled for 21 years so you would think 5% would be a good base case. Effectively 3 revolutions in Russia in the last century so that would come up with more like 3%. Potentially you could bump that up a bit because of the current unrest, but this is the 2nd or 3rd period of some unrest I can recollect. Overall hard to be higher than 4 or 5% that he is “overthrown” without taking a very strong view on the current unrest dynamics. However, other scenarios where this resolved yes would include death (just under 2% for his age on the social security mortality tables I believe, his maybe a bit better) or a “shake up” - maybe he becomes head of the party and senator for life but installs someone else as President. Hard to put a number on that one. His time as PM was driven by the constitution and that has changed, but may have shown him he does not need to be President to wield all the power. Overall I am happy to be a bit above the crowd at 4%.

Putin does not want to leave in the near future. So the real risk is for him to be removed. This is highly unlikely as his position is strong in the society overall, in the military and law enforcement specifically. Therefore unless there is an accident or illness that we do not know about then it is best to assume that he will stay in power.
Initial forecast. Not sure it is such a black swan event. Perhaps Greenland will offer asylum. ;-)

Putin seems to have no plans to leave office voluntarily until 2036 at the earliest.[1]  This leads me to believe there is little chance he would leave of his own volition.  The second, real question is whether we believe he will be driven from office by a popular revolt or a military coup.  I find either outcome highly unlikely given Putin's iron grip on the military and security services.  He also seems to enjoy enormous popularity with the Russian public, according to independent pollsters in Russia, who give him a current approval rating of 64%, a level that most Western democratic leaders can only envy.[2]  This approval rating takes into account the domestic crackdown following the nationwide protests in support of opposition leader Alexei Navalny.  The internationally peer-reviewed results on the Russian COVID vaccine, showing a 92% efficacy, also boost Putin's ability to remain in power long after January 2022.[3] [1] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-russia-politics/putin-approves-changes-allowing-him-to-stay-in-power-until-2036-idUSKBN20X1FD
[2] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-russia-politics-navalny/putins-approval-rating-holds-steady-despite-navalny-crackdown-poll-idUSKBN2A429G
[3] https://www.bbc.com/news/health-55900622
At this level of improbability, assassination, unreported health problems, and unknown unknowns dominate.

With lifetime immunity in place as per the above links and no apparent successor in place, ill-health and or death are the only reasons I can see Putin ceasing to be in office on 1 Jan 2022. Granted, on a recent TV report, he looked a bit wobbly and not his usual self but more recent footage in a speech given at WEF, shows him in a better light; https://bit.ly/3a9fXzq starting at 27:28. Nonetheless speculation continues to circulate about his health - http://dailym.ai/3rF9l1j and the Ukrainian Intelligence Agency holds a transfer of power process is already under way - https://bit.ly/3aXfBep & https://bit.ly/3qbnP8P. However, a Kremlin released video disputes this, not surprisingly; - https://cnn.it/3aS94kT. Thus, for the time being, I'll go with the crowd while I research and monitor.    
@Mark_T as you say, he'll likely want to be wheeled out in a gurney!

Starting at the base of the "highly improbable" range.  To leave in this year would seem like a form of capitulation to the Navalny protestors: a concept which Putin is likely to hold a long and very personal revulsion for [1]. Even if the (highly speculative) speculation about his health has some foundation in truth, the above point will have pushed him into wanting some air time between protests and his departure. This podcast [2] is an excellent narrative of the "power prison" Putin has built for himself, and how his departure only becomes likely when the convoluted web of alliances, dependencies, appeasements, bribes, threats etc. can be maintained and assured as his personal legacy. Few obvious successors being prepped for imminent elevation [3] and no easy alternative mechanism to avoid the predicted (and highly destructive) power struggles that might result from a "wrong pick".  The petrochemical centric Russian economy seems to be on fragile (if stable) ground and is destined for a slow recovery [4]. All these factors put together seem to make a willing & voluntary departure this year unlikely, and given the now stereotypical Russian "flexibility" with the truth any forced departure on health & fitness grounds will likely only come when the diminutive Tsar is wheeled out of the Kremlin on a gurney. [1] https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-32066222
[2] https://www.audible.co.uk/pd/Putin-Prisoner-of-Power-Audiobook/B07W4WVNXK
[3] https://www.politico.eu/article/who-will-replace-valdimir-putin-russia-kremlin/
[4] https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/01/07/russia-in-2021-will-the-economy-recover-a72455
Seems like the rumors are old and the main new factor is the protests, but seems very unlikely he would step down or be ousted.
There have been no credible reports of Putin planning to step down and the current protest movement seems unlikely to remove him from power.
